channel.title: Drunken-JAR-Loader
channel.description:
If you're continuously having to tell your players to "go download the latest jar" or "i updated the client go get it" this is probably for you
This code base will allow your users to always have the most up-to-date version of your client. This is nothing more than a basic loader with splash support and a base for look&feel.
Simply edit the variables to match your needs and it should run out of the box. [code=java] private final static String FRAME_IMAGE = "http://i.imgur.com/UW5ZfQ5.jpg"; private final static String JAR_URL = "http://codeusa.net/play/client.jar"; private final static String LOADER_IMAGE = "http://codeusa.net/images/logo.png"; private static String MAIN_CLASS = "RunClient";// main class of remote jar[/code]
[img]http://img542.imageshack.us/img542/926/zuxm.png[/img] Have fun
https://github.com/Codeusa/Drunken-JAR-Loader

item.title: Drunken-JAR-Loader
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“Codeusa11, post:7, topic:541107”][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=659975.msg4413101#msg4413101 date=1394585074]
To save bandwidth (although small) and to increase loading times I have a suggestion.
[/quote]

@Step 1:
1: Why would you need a “versions.txt” you realize you can simply check the length of your local file to the length of your remote file right? You can even check your “version” attribute to the remote version attribute. There is no need to make any new files. Dozens of ways to check if your file is outdated.

@Step 2:
1: The benefit of class loading is that the end user doesn’t have to get any more files than they need, stored on their computer. There is no harm in serving a 800kb to 3mb file each time they want to play, this is the average amount of bandwidth used when loading webpages nowadays.

@Step 3 see Step 1:

If you want what you suggested make a fork and do it.[/quote]
Shit the entire thing could be brought down to just the MD5 of the file. Just remember, not everybody is in an area with high bandwidth. Shit, I’m paying $50 a month for 10GB of bandwidth because DishNET is the only company that serves internet in my area. Helps to conserve.

As for making a fork and editing for my own use. I have no need for this. I was simply suggesting. I’ve stopped RSPS dev years ago.

Read full topic

item.title: Drunken-JAR-Loader
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

To save bandwidth (although small) and to increase loading times I have a suggestion.

Instead of it from loading the entire JAR at startup from the URL and starting it up. Try this small startup method. (I used this for a easy and simple desktop loader on an old RSPS and even caried it over to other java products I worked on.

Step 1: (Getting and checking current installed and newest versions)
1 - Check if version.txt exists within the cache directory. If not, assume this is first startup and move to “Step 2”.
2 - Load version.txt within the cache directory (setable via a string) and then compare that to a version.txt retreived from a URL.
3 - Compare the two, if they match, procede to “Step 3”. If not, continue to Step 2:

Step 2: (Getting the new JAR)
1 - Check if old JAR exists, if so, delete it.
2 - Start downloading new JAR to the cache directory.
3 - Once new JAR is done downloading, (optional) check its MD5 with one stored online.
4 - If everything checks out, delete old version.txt and make new one with the version now installed. Then move to Step 3.

Step 3: (Starting the new JAR)
1 - Check to make sure the JAR exists, if so, check its MD5 with one stored online of newest version.
2 - If it doesn’t match, backup to Step 2 (Maybe have the MD5 check also with the version.txt checking, but this is how I did it)
3 - If it matches, start the JAR like normal and continue all normal operations.

Shouldn’t take much more work except a “JAR” directory or somewhere on your site to store the JAR, a version.txt, and a JAR.md5 that all can be stored on a website, NOT dropbox. To make updating very easy I created a simple PHP page that I made a updating program in JAVA that would upload the new JAR to the proper place (deleting old one first) then open the PHP page to set the MD5 and new version.txt strings.

Read full topic
